user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of detect_cpu_core_count:
```c
static unsigned int
detect_cpu_core_count (void)
{
  int sys_cpu_count;
  sys_cpu_count = mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count ();
  if (0 >= sys_cpu_count)
  {
    int proc_cpu_count;
    fprintf (stderr, "Failed to detect the number of logical CPU cores "
             "available on the system.\n");
    proc_cpu_count = mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count ();
    if (0 < proc_cpu_count)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "The number of CPU cores available for this process "
               "is used as a fallback.\n");
      sys_cpu_count = proc_cpu_count;
    }
#ifdef MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT
    if (0 >= sys_cpu_count)
    {
      fprintf (stderr, "configure-detected hardcoded number is used "
               "as a fallback.\n");
      sys_cpu_count = MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT;
    }
#endif
    if (0 >= sys_cpu_count)
      sys_cpu_count = 1;
    printf ("Assuming %d logical CPU core%s on this system.\n", sys_cpu_count,
            (1 == sys_cpu_count) ? "" : "s");
  }
  else
  {
    printf ("Detected %d logical CPU core%s on this system.\n", sys_cpu_count,
            (1 == sys_cpu_count) ? "" : "s");
  }
  return (unsigned int) sys_cpu_count;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No statically unreachable code was found in the provided function. Every branch in the function can be reached depending on run-time results of the external calls (mhd_tool_get_system_cpu_count and mhd_tool_get_proc_cpu_count) and on build-time configuration (the presence/absence and value of MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT). The outer if/else is taken when the system count is <=0 or >0 respectively. The proc_cpu_count branch is reachable when the process-level call returns >0. The #ifdef MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT block is conditionally compiled and therefore either present and potentially reachable, or absent (not part of the project); it does not represent unreachable code in the project as a whole. The final fallback (if (0 >= sys_cpu_count) sys_cpu_count = 1) is reachable when both system and proc detections fail and no positive MHD_REAL_CPU_COUNT is available. Because reachability depends on external return values and compile-time configuration, there is no code fragment that is unconditionally unreachable in all configurations and executions of the project.
